title: High-Order Multi-Task Feature Learning to Identify Longitudinal Phenotypic Markers for Alzheimer Disease Progression Prediction

author: Hua Wang, Department of Electrical Engineering & Computer Science, Colorado School of Mines

segmentation: Good afternoon everyone.
It is my great pleasure to present our paper high Order Multi Task feature learning to identify a longitudinal phenotypic markers for ultimate disease progression prediction.

The backgrounds and motivations.
So many major diseases are important concerns in modern modern society such as neurodegenerative disorders and cancers.
Recent research has shown that neurodegenerative disorders are closely connected to regional and functional changes on the patient.

In so if we could elucidate the interrelationship between the variation of human brains as well and the progression of the disease, then it could help us to better diagnose, diagnose the disease, and treat the patient.
So this is meant target of this paper.
